metadata.title: Zinc oxide as efficient additive to cesium ion-exchanged zeolite X catalyst for side-chain alkylation of toluene with methanol
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Amusa Rabindran B. Jermy Abdullah M. Aitani Sulaiman S. Al-Khattaf ⁎ Center of Research Excellence in Petroleum Refining and Petrochemicals, King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals, Dhahran 31261, Saudi Arabia Center of Research Excellence in Petroleum Refining and Petrochemicals King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals Dhahran 31261 Saudi Arabia ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 Present address: 5-10-2-3, Nishino, Nishi-ku, Sapporo 063-0035, Japan. Graphical abstract Side-chain alkylation of toluene with methanol to form styrene and ethylbenzene was studied over cesium ion-exchanged zeolite X (Cs-X) with various catalyst additives to find out effective catalyst systems for styrene formation as well as to elucidate the roles of the additives. Out of 13 types of additives examined, only ZnO exerted substantial positive effects on both toluene conversion and styrene selectivity. The role of ZnO was estimated to promote conversion of methanol to formaldehyde on the basis of IR study of adsorbed methanol. The formation of formaldehyde accelerated the formation of styrene as well as suppressed the transfer hydrogenation of styrene with methanol to form ethylbenzene. The positive effect of ZnO was also observed for Cs-X containing Cs+ in excess of ion-exchange capacity (Cs2O-Cs-X). The negative effect of additives such as Al2O3 was suggested to be caused by the formation of CO2 by water gas shift reaction and Bourdouard reaction. Keywords Cs-X ZnO Side-chain alkylation Styrene Methanol 1 Introduction The reaction of toluene with methanol to produce styrene is a potential route which may replace the conventional two-step route to styrene by alkylation of benzene with ethylene to ethylbenzene followed by dehydrogenation. The reaction was first reported by Sidorenko et al. in 1967 that alkali ion-exchanged zeolite X’s (K-X and Rb-X) showed activity [1]. Soon after this, Yahima et al. reported that cesium ion-exchange zeolite X (Cs-X) was also active [2]. Since then, Cs-X has been most frequently studied as a base catalyst on which various modifications were made to improve the activity and selectivity to styrene. It is widely accepted that the side-chain alkylation proceeds through dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde which undergoes aldol-like condensation with toluene to form styrene. Ethylbenzene is always formed together with styrene. The formation of ethylbenzene was assumed to originate from hydrogenation of styrene with molecular hydrogen which was produced by decomposition of methanol and dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde. We have recently examined the pathway to ethylbenzene by comparing the rate of hydrogenation of styrene with H2 with that of transfer hydrogenation of styrene with methanol. It was concluded that ethylbenzene is primarily produced by transfer hydrogenation of styrene with methanol. Hydrogenation with molecular hydrogen contributes to the formation of ethylbenzene to a smaller extent as compared with the transfer hydrogenation [3]. Two functions are required for the catalyst with high activity: dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde, and activation of toluene to form benzyl anion. Both functions are related to the basic sites of the catalyst. It was suggested that the dehydrogenation of methanol might proceed on weakly basic sites and the activation of toluene might proceed on strongly basic sites [4]. In addition, suppression of transfer hydrogenation of styrene with methanol is desirable to increase the styrene selectivity. For improvement of activity and selectivity, many attempts have been undertaken by modification of Cs-X with chemical compounds containing various elements such as B, P, Cu, Ag, Ce, Cr, Mn, Fe, Zn etc. by different methods such as ion-exchange, impregnation and physical mixing [5–11]. We reported that modification of Cs-X with Cs2O by impregnation and with ZrB2O5 by physical mixing resulted in an improved catalytic performance [12,13]. Addition of Cs2O by impregnation of Cs-X with Cs+ ions increased the activity but decreased the styrene selectivity. On the other hand, addition of ZrB2O5 to Cs-X increased both activity and styrene selectivity only when ZrB2O5 was added by physical mixing. Addition of Zr and B by impregnation from aqueous solution was not effective. The role of the effective additives is supposed to promote selective dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde. Dehydrogenation is suggested to proceed over the sites of basic properties. There might be basic additives other than ZrB2O5 that act as an efficient catalyst for dehydrogenation of methanol to form formaldehyde. The aim of the present study is to find out effective additives to Cs-X for styrene formation from toluene and methanol as well as to elucidate the roles of additives in the reaction mechanisms. Preferable additives are considered to have such properties that exhibit a high activity for conversion of methanol to formaldehyde. There are, however, no catalytic studies of selective dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde, partly because formaldehyde is unstable and decomposes or dimerizes easily, and is difficult to analyze by gas chromatography. Instead of methanol dehydrogenation, ethanol dehydrogenation could be referred. Catalysts which showed a high activity for ethanol dehydrogenation were selected to be examined as additives to Cs-X. Among a variety of additives, we found that ZnO was the best additive in enhancing the toluene conversion and styrene selectivity. Then, mixed oxides containing ZnO were prepared and examined as additives to Cs-X. Roles of additives were also studied by IR of adsorbed methanol. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts used in the present study were composed of Cs ion-exchanged X zeolite (Cs-X) and additives. Cs-X and additives in weight ratio of 9: 1 were physically mixed in a dry state with a mortar for 30min followed by calcination at 723K in air. The Cs-X was prepared by ion-exchange of zeolite X (Na-X) (Junsei Chemicals, Japan) with aqueous CsOH as described in our preceding paper [12]. Ion-exchange degree was 54%. The catalyst which included Cs ions in excess of ion exchange capacity (Cs2OCs-X) was prepared by impregnation of the Cs-X with CsOH aqueous solution. The concentration of Cs2O other than ion-exchanged Cs+ ions was 4.1wt% Cs2O which corresponded to 0.6 Cs atoms per super cage. As single component metal oxide additives, ZnO, CuO, ZrO2, Al2O3, K2CO3, MoO2 and V2O3 were prepared. As ZnO containing mixed oxides, ZnO-SnO2, SiO2-ZnO, and ZnO-SiO2-MgO were prepared. In addition, ZrB2O5 which was found to be an effective additive in our preceding papers [12,13] was also prepared to compare the effectiveness of the additives. ZnO and CuO were prepared from aqueous Zn(NO3)2 and Cu(NO3)2, respectively, by precipitation with NH4OH at pH 8 followed by washing, drying and calcining at 723K in air. ZrO2 was obtained by calcination of hydrated zirconium oxide supplied from Catalysis Society of Japan (ZRO-2) at 873K in air. Al2O3 was Sigma-Aldrich, gamma alumina. K2CO3 was supplied from Aldrich and calcined at 773K. V2O3 and MoO2 were prepared from V2O5 and MoO3, respectively, by reduction with H2 at 773K according to Nakamura et al. [14]. These catalysts were reported to exhibit selective formation of acetaldehyde from ethanol. Mixed oxides containing ZnO were kindly supplied from Prof. Y. Yoshinaga, Tokyo Gakugei University. They were prepared from 0.1N HNO3 aqueous solution of metal salts, urea and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) in calculated ratios by hydrothermal treatment at 373K for 48h, followed by calcination. For SiO2-ZnO (Si/Zn=1/1 atomic ratio), Zn(NO3)2 and TEOS were used and calcined at 723K (SiO2-ZnO(450)) or at 823K (SiO2-ZnO(550)). For ZnO-SnO2 (Si/Sn=1/1 atomic ratio), Zn(NO3)2 and SnCl4 were used and calcined at 823K. For ZnO-SiO2-MgO (Zn/Si/Mg=0.03/1/1 atomic ratio), Zn(NO3)2, Mg(NO3)2 and TEOS were used and calcined at 723K. These ZnO containing mixed oxides were selective catalysts for acetaldehyde from ethanol [15]. ZrB2O5 was prepared from Zr(NO3)4 and Na2B4O7 according to Khundker et al. [16]. Specific surface areas were measured by BET method with Micrometrics ASAP 2020 after pretreatment at 573K in a vacuum. 2.2 Reaction procedures A flow type reactor was employed for carrying out the reaction. A catalyst sample of 400mg sieved into 40–80mesh was placed in the reactor and pretreated in a nitrogen stream at 723K for 1h prior to the reaction. A mixture containing toluene, methanol and nitrogen in 1:1:2.3 molar ratio was fed at a rate of 3.2mmolmin−1 over 400mg of catalyst at 683K. The products were periodically analyzed by on-line gas chromatography with an FID detector. The main products were styrene and ethylbenzene in addition to the reactants, toluene and methanol. Light hydrocarbons were detected, but their quantities were less than 5% of styrene produced, and excluded from the product quantification. Toluene conversion, styrene selectivity in C8 products, styrene yield, and methanol conversion were calculated by the following equations. “Styrene selectivity in C8 products” is expressed by “styrene selectivity” hereafter. Tolueneconversion(mol%)=(1−[toluene outlet]/[toluene fed])×100mol% Styreneselectivity(mol%)=([styrene]/[all C8 products])×100mol% Styreneyield(mol%)=(Toluene conversion×Styrene selectivity)/100mol% Methanolconversion(mol%)=(1−[methanol outlet]/[methanol inlet])×100mol% Since the products originating from toluene were exclusively styrene and ethylbenzene, the styrene selectivity was practically calculated by {[styrene]/([styrene]+[ethylbenzene])}×100mol% 2.3 FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed methanol Catalyst sample was pressed into a thin wafer (∼50mg/20mm dia) and placed in an in-situ cell with CaF2 windows. The sample was pretreated at 723K for 1h in a vacuum, and exposed to 3kPa methanol at 623K for 3min followed by cooling to room temperature. Then, the sample was heated again to 623K for 30min without evacuation of the IR cell. The sample was heated further at 683K for 30min. All spectra were measured at room temperature with Nicolet 6700 FT-IR. 2.4 XRD Powdered XRD patterns of the samples were measured with Rigaku Miniflex II XRD powder diffraction system, Cu-Kα being used as a radiation source at 30kV and 15mA. 2.5 SEM measurement SEM images were measured with a JOEL JSM-5800 scanning microscope. Prior to the measurement, the samples were loaded on a sample holder, held with conductive aluminum tape and coated with a film of gold in vacuo with Cressington sputter ion-coater for 20s with 15mA current. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effects of different additives Specific surface areas of Cs-X and additives are listed in Table 1 . As the atomic weights of Cs and Na are 132.9 and 23.0, respectively, ion-exchange of the raw material (Na-X) with Cs+ ions results in a decrease in the specific surface area. The surface area of Cs-X normalized to unit weight of the original Na-X is also presented in parenthesis. The same normalization was also done for Cs2O-Cs-X. The toluene conversion and styrene selectivity are shown in Figs. 1 and 2 for selected catalysts. Since the addition of ZnO was found to be effective, the results for ZnO added to Cs-X and Cs2O-Cs-X are shown in Fig. 1. Some additives were inert or caused negative effects. The results of selected catalysts which showed negative effects of the additives are shown in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 1, addition of ZnO to Cs-X resulted in substantial increases in both toluene conversion and styrene selectivity. The same positive effects of addition of ZnO were observed for Cs2O-Cs-X. ZnO as an effective additive to Cs-X and Cs2O-Cs-X is a new finding of the present study. Some additives exhibited negative effects as shown in Fig. 2. As the amount of additives was 10wt%, the conversion would be 90% of that observed for Cs-X if the additives acted as an inert. The toluene conversions for CuO/Cs-X, MoO2/Cs-X and Al2O3/Cs-X were less than 90% of that obtained for Cs-X. In particular, the toluene conversion for Al2O3/Cs-X and V2O3/Cs-X were less than 30% of that for Cs-X. The negative effects are discussed in subsection 3.3 in association with IR study of adsorbed methanol. Toluene conversions and styrene selectivities for all catalysts at a time on stream of 50min are summarized in Table 2 . Methanol conversions are also included. It is to be noted, dimethyl ether (DME) was also included in the products for Al2O3/Cs-X, V2O5/Cs-X, MoO2/Cs-X and ZrO2/Cs-X; the amounts of DME to the amounts of methanol remained in the products were 100, 4, 5, and 4%, respectively. Among the additives examined, only ZnO was found to be significantly effective. The other additives showed almost inert or negative effect. As compared to ZrB2O5 which was reported to be effective additive in our preceding papers [12,13], ZnO is more effective in enhancing toluene conversion and styrene selectivity under the reaction conditions of the present study. Toluene conversions were 4.6 and 3.8% and styrene selectivities were 76.1 and 71.6% over ZnO/Cs-X and ZrB2O5/Cs-X, respectively. Methanol conversion exceeded toluene conversion for all catalysts. In particular, Al2O3/Cs-X and V2O3/Cs-X converted methanol more than 70%. Large amounts of H2 and CO should be formed, though they were not analyzed. 3.2 Effects of ZnO addition to Cs-X and Cs2O-Cs-X 3.2.1 Variation in activity and selectivity with the amount of ZnO added The toluene conversion and styrene selectivity varied with the amount of ZnO added. Fig. 3 shows the variations of toluene conversion and styrene selectivity as a function of the amount of ZnO added to Cs-X. Toluene conversion showed a small maximum at 5wt% of ZnO addition, while the styrene selectivity showed a maximum of 76% at 10wt% of ZnO addition. Addition of ZnO in excess of 10wt% caused a gradual decrease in the selectivity. A maximum yield of styrene 3.5% was obtained for ZnO addition of both 5 and 10wt%. The effects of ZnO addition to Cs2O-Cs-X on toluene conversion and styrene selectivity are shown in Fig. 4 . Toluene conversion showed a maximum value of 7.7% at 5wt% of ZnO addition, and gradual decrease as the amount of ZnO increased to 15wt%. Toluene conversion decreased rapidly on addition of 20wt% ZnO to Cs2O-Cs-X. Styrene selectivity increased slowly with an increase in ZnO addition up to 10wt%, and increased rather rapidly with ZnO addition up to 20wt%. The maximum yield of styrene was 2.6% at ZnO addition of 15wt%. 3.2.2 States of ZnO on Cs-X XRD patterns of Cs-X and ZnO/Cs-X are shown in Fig. 5 . The XRD pattern shown in Fig. 5(A) is typical one observed for Cs-X. The XRD pattern in Fig. 5(B) for ZnO/Cs-X is composed of the pattern of Cs-X and that of ZnO. No indication was observed for structural interaction between Cs-X and ZnO. SEM images of Cs-X and ZnO/Cs-X are shown in Fig. 6 (A) and (B), respectively. It can be seen that Cs-X catalyst consists of crystallites of the size about 2μm, and ZnO/Cs-X catalyst consists of crystallites of the size about 2μm and much smaller particles. It can be assigned that the crystallites of the size about 2μm are Cs-X and the smaller particles are ZnO. In ZnO/Cs-X, the smaller particles of ZnO are dispersed on Cs-X crystallites, which is consistent with that obtained from XRD patters. As expected for physical mixture of Cs-X and ZnO, it is clear that two components of Cs-X and ZnO exist independently without chemical interaction between Cs-X and ZnO. This is our intention to prepare catalysts by grinding two components with a mortar in a dry state. Impregnation of Cs-X with metal salts in aqueous solution would cause ion-exchange of Cs+ ions to eliminate or change the sites in Cs-X. 3.2.3 Change in the state of adsorbed methanol with time and temperature It has been reported by Unland [17] and King and Garces [18] that unidentate formate and bidentate formate are formed on active catalysts for side-chain alkylation of toluene with methanol. Both authors agree that unidentate formate is associated with the reaction. The formation of unidentate formate correlated with the side-chain alkylation while the formation of bidentate formate did not correlate with the reaction. King and Garces suggested that unidentate formate is an intermediate for side-chain alkylation. Unland, however, described that the observed unidentate formate is somehow related to the reaction intermediate, but the possibility could not be excluded that the unidentate formate could simply be a dead end for the decomposition of methanol [17]. Figs. 7, 8 and 9 show IR spectra observed when Cs-X, ZnO/Cs-X and Al2O3/Cs-X, respectively, were exposed to 0.5kPa of methanol for 3min and 30min at 623K, followed by increasing the temperature to 683K and kept for 30min. Three types of the surface species were observed. The bands at 1685 and 1290cm−1 are assigned to unidentate formate, and the bands at 1610 and 1340cm−1 to bidentate formate [18]. The bands at 1640 (twin peaks) (ν asy OCO) and 1380cm−1 (ν sy OCO) which appeared at 683K are assigned to bidentate carbonate [18–21]. Twin peaks indicate two types of bidentate carbonate slightly different in the structure. The band at 1430cm−1 which appeared on the sample before exposure to methanol is assigned to free carbonate (carbonate ion) retained on the surface after pretreatment by evacuation at 723K. On exposure of Cs-X to methanol for 3min at 623K, the bands assigned to bidentate formate were observed as shown in Fig. 7. The weak bands assigned to unidentate formate were also observed. Prolonged heating for 30min did not bring about definite change in spectrum. On heating at 683K for 30min, bidentate carbonate was formed, and unidentate and bidentate formates decreased their intensities to a small extent. On exposure of ZnO/Cs-X to methanol for 3min at 623K, the bands assigned to bidentate formate appeared at 1610 and 1340cm−1 and the bands assigned to unidentate formate appeared at 1685 and 1290cm−1 as shown in Fig. 8. Prolonged heating at 623K for 30min resulted in distinct increases in intensities of the bands assigned to unidentate formate. Heating at 683K for 30min caused decreases in unidentate and bidentate formates. The bands assigned to bidentate carbonate at about 1640 and 1380cm−1 developed on heating at 683K for 30min. On exposure of Al2O3/Cs-X to methanol for 3min at 623K, the bands assigned to bidentate formate were observed, and weak bands assigned to unidentate formate were also observed as shown in Fig. 9. Prolonged heating for 30min developed the bands assigned to both types of formate. Two types of formate were smaller on Al2O3/Cs-X than on ZnO/Cs-X. It is to be noted that bidentate carbonate was formed on heating at 623K for 30min, which was observed neither on Cs-X nor on ZnO/Cs-X under the same condition. On heating at 683K for 30min, the bands assigned to bidentate carbonate developed. Bidentate formate kept its intensity but unidentate formate became very small. For all of ZnO/Cs-X, Cs-X and Al2O3, the formation of bidentate carbonate was observed at 683K. In particular, the formation was observed at 623K for Al2O3. The formation of carbonate was not reported either by Unland [17] nor by King and Garces [18] for Cs-X exposed to methanol at 673K, probably because exposure time was too short. In a recent paper by Han et al. [11], the formation of small amount of CO2 was detected by detailed analysis of gas phase products during the side-chain alkylayion of toluene and methanol. Although the mechanism of CO2 formation was not discussed, their results are consistent with our results obtained at 683K. There are two possible routes through which CO2 is formed. Methanol undergoes various reactions such as dehydrogenation to formaldehyde, decomposition to CO and H2, and dehydration to DME and H2O. Among the reactions which lead to CO2 formation, Boudouard reaction (2CO→CO2 +C) and water gas shift reaction (CO+H2O→CO2 +H2) are considered to be candidates. Al2O3 is well-known dehydration catalyst for methanol to form DME and H2O. Actually the formation of DME was observed over Al2O3/Cs-X in the side-chain alkylation. The formation of bidentate carbonate was observed by IR at a low temperature of 623K. It is plausible that the formation of bidentate carbonate over Al2O3/Cs-X resulted primarily from water gas shift reaction, though Boudourd reaction cannot be excluded. In the case of ZnO/Cs-X and Cs-X, on the other hand, dehydration of methanol would not occur, no H2O formation being expected. Accordingly, the formation of CO2 would result from Bourdouard reaction of CO which was formed by decomposition of methanol. During the reaction of side-chain alkylation of toluene with methanol, H2O is formed by the aldol-like condensation of toluene with formaldehyde. In this case, water gas shift reaction may take place even on ZnO/Cs-X and Cs-X in addition to Bourdouard reaction to form CO2. 3.3 Roles of ZnO and other additives Although we have examined in this study a variety of metal oxides and mixed metal oxides as additives to Cs-X, only ZnO was found to show substantially positive effects on the toluene conversion and styrene selectivity. The other additives behaved inert or exerted negative effects. Since formaldehyde reacts directly with toluene to form styrene, the formation of formaldehyde is a crucial reaction to promote the side-chain alkylation. The positive effects of ZnO on both toluene conversion and styrene selectivity result from a high ability of ZnO to form formaldehyde as evidenced by IR study of adsorbed methanol as shown in Fig. 7. The increase in styrene selectivity is considered to result from suppression of the transfer hydrogenation of styrene with methanol to ethylbenzene and formaldehyde. Since formaldehyde is a product of the transfer hydrogenation, the formation of formaldehyde accelerates the reverse reaction of the transfer hydrogenation, and thus suppresses the transfer hydrogenation forming ethylbenzene. Mechanism proposed for the formation of styrene on the basis of IR study is shown in Scheme 1 . Although unidentate formate is related with the catalytic activity, the surface species that reacts with benzyl anion to form styrene through 2-phenylethanol may not be unidentate formate, but may be polalized formaldehyde. The polalized formaldehyde is formed by adsorption of formaldehyde on metal cations of the catalyst surface. Both unidentate formate and polalized formaldehyde are in adsorption equilibrium with formaldehyde in gas phase. The surface concentration of polalized formaldehyde is proportional to that of unidentate formate. The higher the concentration of unidentate formate, the higher the concentration of polalized formaldehyde. A high concentration of polalized formaldehyde results in a fast production of 2-phenylethanol which rapidly undergoes dehydration to styrene by aldol-like condensation. The additives other than ZnO showed no positive effects. Our assumption that the catalysts showing a high activity for ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde would also show a high activity for methanol to formaldehyde was not to the point. Active sites are not the same for ethanol dehydrogenation and methanol dehydrogenation. The addition of Al2O3 to Cs-X resulted in a decrease in the toluene conversion to less than 1/3 of that observed for Cs-X without additive. Because of physical mixture of additives and Cs-X, the surface properties of Cs-X would not be changed by chemical interaction with the additives. The active sites on Cs-X would not be poisoned directly by the additives. Negative effects would be caused by some reasons other than chemical interaction of Cs-X with additives. One of the possible causes for the negative effect is the formation of a compound which acts as a poison to the sites on Cs-X. As discussed in Section 3.2.3, CO2 is easily formed on Al2O3/Cs-X. The basic sites on Cs-X would be strongly poisoned by CO2, and, accordingly, toluene conversion was decreased to less than 90% of the activity of Cs-X by adding 10% Al2O3. The styrene selectivity, however, increased on addition of Al2O3 in contrast to a decrease in toluene conversion. Most plausible reason for this is that the reaction of toluene with formaldehyde to ethylbenzene is a successive reaction in which styrene and ethylbenzene are primary and secondary products, respectively. In the successive reaction, the selectivity to the primary product decreases with conversion. An additional reason might be that CO2 formed on Al2O3/Cs-X would be adsorbed more selectively on the sites for transfer hydrogenation of styrene with methanol than on the sites for aldol-like reaction of toluene with formaldehyde. In this case, the transfer ydrogenation would be retarded by CO2 more extensively than the aldol-like reaction, resulting in an increase in the styrene selectivity. 4 Conclusions 1. Addition of ZnO to Cs-X and Cs2O/Cs-X substantially increases both toluene conversion and selectivity to styrene. 2. Role of ZnO is to convert methanol to formaldehyde, which enhances styrene formation, and suppresses transfer hydrogenation of styrene to ethylbenzene. 3. Water gas shift reaction and Bourdouard reaction forming CO2 involved in the side chain alkylation suppress the toluene conversion. coredata.dc:description: Side-chain alkylation of toluene with methanol to form styrene and ethylbenzene was studied over cesium ion-exchanged zeolite X (Cs-X) with various catalyst additives to find out effective catalyst systems for styrene formation as well as to elucidate the roles of the additives. Out of 13 types of additives examined, only ZnO exerted substantial positive effects on both toluene conversion and styrene selectivity. The role of ZnO was estimated to promote conversion of methanol to formaldehyde on the basis of IR study of adsorbed methanol. The formation of formaldehyde accelerated the formation of styrene as well as suppressed the transfer hydrogenation of styrene with methanol to form ethylbenzene. The positive effect of ZnO was also observed for Cs-X containing Cs+ in excess of ion-exchange capacity (Cs2O-Cs-X). The negative effect of additives such as Al2O3 was suggested to be caused by the formation of CO2 by water gas shift reaction and Bourdouard reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Zinc oxide as efficient additive to cesium ion-exchanged zeolite X catalyst for side-chain alkylation of toluene with methanol
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
